Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how language is used differently at home and school depending on the relationships between people
Elaboration: Asking relevant questions and expressing requests and opinions in ways that suit the contexts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •models of the language used in informal peer conversations and more formal teacher/student dialogue

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how language is used differently at home and school depending on the relationships between people
Elaboration: Learning to use language according to the relationship between people; for example, between a parent and a child, a teacher and a student, siblings or friends, shopkeepers and customers

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore different ways of using language to express preferences, likes and dislikes
Elaboration: Recognising how feelings and preferences might be communicated in speech and gesture
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using visual supports and role play to model expressing feelings and preferences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore different ways of using language to express preferences, likes and dislikes
Elaboration: Recognising the ways emotions and feelings can be conveyed in visual and media texts; for example, in advertising and animations

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that texts can take many forms, such as signs, books and digital texts
Elaboration: Comparing images in informative and imaginative texts and identifying similarities and differences
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •sharing texts from the students’ culture and home language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that texts can take many forms, such as signs, books and digital texts
Elaboration: Comparing different ways information might be presented; for example, on a sign or in a set of instructions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that texts can take many forms, such as signs, books and digital texts
Elaboration: Identifying different forms of texts in school, home and community settings; for example, crossing signs, hand washing signs, directions and product labels

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that texts can take many forms, such as signs, books and digital texts
Elaboration: Understanding that many first nations australians' stories are oral narrations and cultural accounts, and may be represented as or with images

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand conventions of print and screen, including how books and simple digital texts are usually organised
Elaboration: Learning that standard australian english in written texts is read from left to right, and usually from top to bottom of the page
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •demonstrations of the print representation of spoken texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand conventions of print and screen, including how books and simple digital texts are usually organised
Elaboration: Identifying tabs in a digital text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand conventions of print and screen, including how books and simple digital texts are usually organised
Elaboration: Discussing the placement of images and words in text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand conventions of print and screen, including how books and simple digital texts are usually organised
Elaboration: Indicating the title of a book and where to start reading

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise that sentences are key units for expressing ideas
Elaboration: Learning that word order in sentences is important for meaning; for example, "the boy sat on the dog." "the dog sat on the boy."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •repeated oral models of a range of sentences and opportunities to practise them

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise that sentences are key units for expressing ideas
Elaboration: Recognising the difference between a sentence fragment and a sentence; for example, "after school" "dad will pick me up after school."

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise that sentences are made up of groups of words that work together in particular ways to make meaning
Elaboration: Learning how words in a sentence relate to one another; for example, connecting a cat (noun) to ate (verb), or black (adjective) to a cat (noun)
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •practising sentences supported with gestures, objects and images to demonstrate the meaning of any new vocabulary

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Explore the contribution of images and words to meaning in stories and informative texts
Elaboration: Recognising that texts can be interpreted differently when only the words or only the images are read or viewed
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •use of images that are culturally sensitive or support in understanding images which have a cultural context

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Explore the contribution of images and words to meaning in stories and informative texts
Elaboration: Identifying where written text is reflected in accompanying images and where written text is not captured in images

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise and develop awareness of vocabulary used in familiar contexts, related to everyday experiences, personal interests and topics taught at school
Elaboration: Identifying learning area-specific words when learning new topics or engaging in imaginative play; for example, role-playing a shopkeeper and a customer
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •learning words in meaningful groups such as adjective + noun with visual and physical prompts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise and develop awareness of vocabulary used in familiar contexts, related to everyday experiences, personal interests and topics taught at school
Elaboration: Identifying words for a topic studied at school; for example, words relevant to the topic of families

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise and develop awareness of vocabulary used in familiar contexts, related to everyday experiences, personal interests and topics taught at school
Elaboration: Expanding vocabulary through informal interactions and planned experiences with adults and peers, texts, images and artefacts or objects

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify punctuation as a feature of written text different from letters; recognise that capital letters are used for names, and that capital letters also signal the beginning of sentences, while punctuation marks signal the end
Elaboration: Commenting on capital letters encountered in everyday texts; for example, "that's the letter that starts my name." "the name of my family and my town have capital letters."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •understanding the relationship between the symbol, its meaning and its function through teacher modelling when reading aloud.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Share ideas about stories, poems and images in literature, reflecting on experiences that are similar or different to their own, by engaging with texts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Engaging with texts that reflect the social and cultural groups to which students belong

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Share ideas about stories, poems and images in literature, reflecting on experiences that are similar or different to their own, by engaging with texts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Comparing experiences depicted in stories by wide-ranging world authors with own experiences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Share ideas about stories, poems and images in literature, reflecting on experiences that are similar or different to their own, by engaging with texts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Viewing stories by first nations australian storytellers from print, visual, digital and multimodal sources

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Share ideas about stories, poems and images in literature, reflecting on experiences that are similar or different to their own, by engaging with texts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Engaging with texts that portray australian family life in different settings across australia; for example, suburban and remote settings

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Share ideas about stories, poems and images in literature, reflecting on experiences that are similar or different to their own, by engaging with texts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Identifying some features of culture that are revealed by characters and events in stories; for example, dress, food and daily routines

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Respond to stories, and share feelings and thoughts about their events and characters
Elaboration: Using drawing and beginning forms of writing to express personal responses to stories, poems or films

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Respond to stories, and share feelings and thoughts about their events and characters
Elaboration: Discussing events and characters in texts and connecting them to their own experiences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise different types of literary texts, and identify features, including events, characters and beginnings and endings
Elaboration: Recognising that stories often have similar beginnings; for example, "once upon a time" "a long long time ago" in fairytales, or introducing the character: "a girl called amira ..."

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise different types of literary texts, and identify features, including events, characters and beginnings and endings
Elaboration: Exploring literature by first nations australian authors and their cultural patterns of storytelling

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise different types of literary texts, and identify features, including events, characters and beginnings and endings
Elaboration: Identifying how stories are told in poetry

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise different types of literary texts, and identify features, including events, characters and beginnings and endings
Elaboration: Identifying typical features of fairytales, such as princes and princesses or the moral of the story

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore and replicate the rhythms and sound patterns of literary texts, such as poems, rhymes and songs
Elaboration: Using music and actions to enhance appreciation of rhymes, poems, chants and songs

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore and replicate the rhythms and sound patterns of literary texts, such as poems, rhymes and songs
Elaboration: Reciting rhymes with actions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore and replicate the rhythms and sound patterns of literary texts, such as poems, rhymes and songs
Elaboration: Exploring rhythms used in poems by first nations australians

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Retell and adapt familiar literary texts through play, performance, images or writing
Elaboration: Drawing and role-playing characters or events
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •modelling of past tense verbs, particularly common irregular verbs, such as ‘went’ ‘saw’ ‘took’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Retell and adapt familiar literary texts through play, performance, images or writing
Elaboration: Sequencing pictures, which may involve using digital tools to retell a story

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify some familiar texts, such as stories and informative texts, and their purpose
Elaboration: Recognising symbols in everyday environments and discussing why they are used; for example, exit signs, school crossing signs, emblems or badges on school uniforms

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify some familiar texts, such as stories and informative texts, and their purpose
Elaboration: Using book covers to group imaginative and informative texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify some familiar texts, such as stories and informative texts, and their purpose
Elaboration: Grouping texts according to topic; for example, grouping a set of texts, which may include informative and imaginative texts about farm animals

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Interact in informal and structured situations by listening while others speak, and using features of voice, including volume levels
Elaboration: Exchanging ideas with peers in pairs and small groups, engaging in class discussions, listening to others and contributing ideas
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •supported interaction in pairs or smaller groups to model the language required for learning until they gain confidence

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Interact in informal and structured situations by listening while others speak, and using features of voice, including volume levels
Elaboration: Exchanging ideas with peers in pairs and small groups, engaging in class discussions, listening to others and contributing ideas
EALDElaboration: •modelling of how questions are formed and opportunities to practise question structures orally

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Interact in informal and structured situations by listening while others speak, and using features of voice, including volume levels
Elaboration: Showing understanding of appropriate listening behaviour, such as listening without interrupting and looking at the speaker, if culturally appropriate

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Interact in informal and structured situations by listening while others speak, and using features of voice, including volume levels
Elaboration: Altering volume for inside and outside situations and when speaking to an audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Interact in informal and structured situations by listening while others speak, and using features of voice, including volume levels
Elaboration: Participating in informal interaction situations; for example, play-based experiences that involve the imaginative use of spoken language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Interact in informal and structured situations by listening while others speak, and using features of voice, including volume levels
Elaboration: Listening to and following instructions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify some differences between imaginative and informative texts
Elaboration: Talking about what is "real" and what is imagined in texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify some differences between imaginative and informative texts
Elaboration: Identifying and selecting texts for information purposes and commenting on how the text might help with a task

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify some differences between imaginative and informative texts
Elaboration: Comparing images in imaginative texts with images in informative texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read decodable and authentic texts, using developing phonic knowledge, and monitor meaning using context and emerging grammatical knowledge
Elaboration: Navigating a text correctly, starting at the right place and reading in the right direction, returning to the next line as needed, and matching one spoken word to one written word
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •reading texts that make use of repetition of vocabulary and syntax so that the vocabulary load is more manageable

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read decodable and authentic texts, using developing phonic knowledge, and monitor meaning using context and emerging grammatical knowledge
Elaboration: Attempting to work out unknown words by using phonic decoding and knowledge of high-frequency words

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read decodable and authentic texts, using developing phonic knowledge, and monitor meaning using context and emerging grammatical knowledge
Elaboration: Pausing or asking for support when meaning breaks down

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning to understand and discuss texts listened to, viewed or read independently
Elaboration: Sequencing ideas in spoken texts, retelling well-known stories, retelling stories with picture cues, retelling information using prompts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •unpacking and linking unfamiliar or new ideas to prior knowledge using visuals, before, during and after reading

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning to understand and discuss texts listened to, viewed or read independently
Elaboration: Listening for specific purposes; for example, details of a character or to answer a given question

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning to understand and discuss texts listened to, viewed or read independently
Elaboration: Relating one or two key facts from informative texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning to understand and discuss texts listened to, viewed or read independently
Elaboration: Retelling events from first nations australians' stories and cultural accounts in sequence

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning to understand and discuss texts listened to, viewed or read independently
Elaboration: Predicting what might happen in a text based on the title and cover

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and participate in shared editing of short written texts to record and report ideas and events, using some learnt vocabulary, basic sentence boundary punctuation and spelling some consonant-vowel-consonant words correctly
Elaboration: Using beginning writing knowledge, sound-letter relationships, known words and punctuation to create short texts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •being given alternative ways to communicate and develop ideas as a transition to creating written texts, for example drawing and sequencing ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and participate in shared editing of short written texts to record and report ideas and events, using some learnt vocabulary, basic sentence boundary punctuation and spelling some consonant-vowel-consonant words correctly
Elaboration: Using writing and drawing, which may include digital tools, to represent and communicate personal responses to ideas and events experienced through texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and participate in shared editing of short written texts to record and report ideas and events, using some learnt vocabulary, basic sentence boundary punctuation and spelling some consonant-vowel-consonant words correctly
Elaboration: "reading" their own texts back to an experienced writer

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and participate in shared editing of short written texts to record and report ideas and events, using some learnt vocabulary, basic sentence boundary punctuation and spelling some consonant-vowel-consonant words correctly
Elaboration: Participating in shared editing by circling the capital letters at the beginning of sentences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and deliver short spoken texts to report ideas and events to peers, using features of voice such as appropriate volume
Elaboration: Sharing a personal experience, interest or discovery with peers in a semi-formal situation
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •listening activities which demonstrate volume, pace and intonation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and deliver short spoken texts to report ideas and events to peers, using features of voice such as appropriate volume
Elaboration: Sharing a personal experience, interest or discovery with peers in a semi-formal situation
EALDElaboration: •use of talk scaffolds

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and deliver short spoken texts to report ideas and events to peers, using features of voice such as appropriate volume
Elaboration: Sharing personal responses to ideas and events experienced through texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and deliver short spoken texts to report ideas and events to peers, using features of voice such as appropriate volume
Elaboration: Using visual prompts to practise staying on topic or to sequence ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Form most lower-case and upper-case letters using learnt letter formations
Elaboration: Following clear demonstrations of how to construct each letter; for example, where to start and in which direction to write

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Form most lower-case and upper-case letters using learnt letter formations
Elaboration: Developing a functional pencil grip/grasp

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and generate rhyming words, alliteration patterns, syllables and sounds (phonemes) in spoken words (phonological awareness)
Elaboration: Recognising and producing rhyming words when listening to rhyming stories or rhymes; for example, "funny" and "money"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •beginning with rhyming words that the students are already familiar with; for example “bat”; ‘”hat”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and generate rhyming words, alliteration patterns, syllables and sounds (phonemes) in spoken words (phonological awareness)
Elaboration: Identifying patterns of alliteration in spoken words; for example, "helpful henry"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and generate rhyming words, alliteration patterns, syllables and sounds (phonemes) in spoken words (phonological awareness)
Elaboration: Identifying syllables in spoken words; for example, clapping the rhythm of "mon-day" "ja-cob" or "si-en-na"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Segment sentences into individual words; orally blend and segment single-syllable spoken words; isolate, blend and manipulate phonemes in single-syllable words (phonological awareness)
Elaboration: Saying the sounds when given a word; for example, "can" ("c-a-n") or "ship" ("sh-i-p")

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Segment sentences into individual words; orally blend and segment single-syllable spoken words; isolate, blend and manipulate phonemes in single-syllable words (phonological awareness)
Elaboration: Saying the word when given the sounds; for example, "l-i-p" ("lip") or "m-u-n-ch" ("munch")

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Segment sentences into individual words; orally blend and segment single-syllable spoken words; isolate, blend and manipulate phonemes in single-syllable words (phonological awareness)
Elaboration: Saying the new word when the beginning phoneme, medial, or end phoneme in a word is replaced with a different phoneme; for example, "run" becomes "fun" or "fun" becomes "fan"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and name all upper- and lower-case letters (graphs), and know the most common sound that each letter represents
Elaboration: Recognising letters in own name
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •understanding the purpose of upper- and lower-case letters, which are not a feature of all languages

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and name all upper- and lower-case letters (graphs), and know the most common sound that each letter represents
Elaboration: Matching upper- and lower-case letters

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and name all upper- and lower-case letters (graphs), and know the most common sound that each letter represents
Elaboration: Identifying sounds for upper- and lower-case letters

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Write consonant-vowel-consonant (cvc) words by representing sounds with the appropriate letters, and blend sounds associated with letters when reading cvc words

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of letters and sounds to spell words
Elaboration: Making plausible spelling choices using letter-sound correspondences and morphemic knowledge
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to identify letters and sounds in the classroom print environment: for example, “d’ in door

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read and write some high-frequency words and other familiar words
Elaboration: Knowing how to read and write some high-frequency words recognised in shared texts and texts being read independently; for example, "and" "my" "is" "the" and "go"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •ensuring students understand the words before writing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read and write some high-frequency words and other familiar words
Elaboration: Knowing how to read and write some familiar words; for example, their name, the name of a character or the name of their school

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that words are units of meaning and can be made of more than one meaningful part
Elaboration: Learning that words are made up of meaningful parts; for example, "dogs" has 2 meaningful parts: "dog" and "s" meaning more than one
